analogous.example: In many ways, the Internet's transformative effect on society has been analogous to that of the printing press.
analogous.meaning: similar in some respects but otherwise different

ascribe.example: History ascribes The Odyssey and The Illiad to Homer, but scholars now debate whether he was a historical figure or a fictitious name.

avert.example: Afraid to see the aftermath of the car crash, I averted my eyes as we drove by.
The struggling videogame company put all of its finances into one final, desperate project to avert bankrupcy.

begrudge.example: Sitting all alone in his room, Harvey begrudged the happiness of the other children playing outside his window.
We never begrudge money spent on ourselves.

behoove.example: The teacher looked down at the student and said, "It would behoove you to be in class on time and complete your homework, so that you don't repeat freshman English for a third straight year."
behoove.meaning: to be one's duty or responsibility; be appropriate or suitable for someone
behoove.meaning_bg: нужно е, подобава, трябва, дълг е

belittle.example: A good teacher will never belittle his students, but will instead empower them.
belittle.meaning: lessen in importance, dismiss as unimportant

besmirch.example: The prince's distasteful choice of words besmirched not only his own name, but the reputation of the entire royal family.

buttress.example: China's economy has been buttressed by a global demand for the electronic parts the country manufactures.

cavalier.example: Percy dismissed the issue with a cavalier wave of his hand.
cavalier.meaning: showing lack of proper concern, offhand or casual; haughty

cerebral.example: A cerebral analysis of most pop music finds it to be simple and childish, but that ignores the point - the music's effect on the listener.
cerebral.meaning: intellectual rather than emotional or physical
cerebral.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

clemency.example: In the final moments of the trial, during his closing speech, Phillips was nearly begging the judge for clemency.

coalesce.example: Over time, the various tribes coalesced into a single common culture with one universal language.
coalesce.meaning_bg: обединявам се, сливам се, сдружавам се

cohesive.example: A well-written, cohesive essay will keep on topic at all times, never losing sight of the main argument.
cohesive.meaning: well integrated, forming a united whole

consecrate.example: At the church of Notre Dame in France, the new High Altar was consecrated in 1182.

conundrum.example: Computers have helped solve some of the mathematical conundrums which have puzzled man for many centuries.

delegate.example: Since the senior manager had to go on many international business trips, she was forced to delegate many of her responsibilities to two lower-level managers.
delegate.meaning: give an assignment to, entrust task or responsibility to another
delegate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

deride.example: The nun derided the students for trying to sneak insects and worms into the classroom.

docile.example: Barnyard animals are considerably more docile than the wild animals.
docile.meaning: obedient, easily managed; willing to be supervised or directed

eccentric.example: Mozart was well-known for his eccentricities, often speaking words backward to confuse those around him.

emulate.example: To really become fluent in a new language, emulate the speech patterns and intonation of people who speak the language.

evenhanded.example: Teachers often have trouble being evenhanded to all of their varied students.

fawn.example: The media fawned over the handsome new CEO, praising his impeccable sense of style instead of asking more pointed questions.
fawn.meaning: try to gain favor by extreme flattery
fawn.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

finagle.example: Steven was able to finagle one of the last seats on the train by convincing the conductor that his torn stub was actually a valid ticket.
finagle.meaning: obtain by dishonest or devious means

foolhardy.example: The police regularly face dangerous situations, so for a police officer not to wear his bullet-proof vest is foolhardy.

forthright.example: I did not expect the insurance agent to give us any straight answers, but I was pleasent surprised by how forthright he was.
forthright.meaning: direct and outspoken, without subtlety or evasion

glean.example: Herb has given us no formal statement about his background, but from various hints, I have gleaned that he grew up in difficult circumstances.
glean.meaning: collect information bit by bit, from various sources

humdrum.example: Having grown up in a humdrum suburb, Jacob relished life in New York City after moving.
humdrum.meaning: lacking excitement or variety, boringly monotonous

implicate.example: By saying that some of the guests were uncomfortable, the manager implicated to the hotel staff that it needed to be more dilligent.
The crime boss was implicated for a long list of crimes, ranging from murder to disturbing the peace.
implicate.meaning: incriminate, show to be involved in a crime

incense.example: When Herb bought football tickets for a game on the day of their wedding anniversary, Jill was incensed.
incense.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

incumbent.example: Middle managers at times make important decisions, but real responsibility for the financial well-being of the corporation is ultimately incumbent on the CEO.
incumbent.meaning: necessary for someone as a duty or responsibility

industrious.example: Pete was an industrious student, completing every assignment thoroughly and on time.

insipid.example: The movie director was known for hiring beautiful actors in order to deflect attention away from the insipid scripts he would typically use.

intermittent.example: The intermittent thunder continued and the night was punctuated by cracks of lightning - a surreal sleepless night.

irascible.example: If Arthur's dog is not fed adequately, he becames highly irascible, even growling at his own shadow.

lethargic.example: Nothing can make a person more lethargic than a big turkey dinner.

melancholy.example: Hamlet is a figure of tremendous melancholy: he doesn't have a truly cheerful scene throughout the entire play.

piquant.example: The chef, with a mere flick of the salt shaker, turned the bland tomato soup into a piquant meal.
piquant.meaning: having a pleasantly sharp taste or appetizing flavor

precarious.example: People smoke to relax and forget their cares, but ironically, in terms of health risks, smoking is far more precarious than either mountain-climbing or skydiving.

preempt.example: A governmental warning about an imminent terrorist attack would preempt ordinary network programming on television.
preempt.meaning: take the place of or have precedence over

presumptuous.example: Many felt that Barney was presumptuous in moving into the large office before the management even made any official announcement of his promotion.

prevail.example: During the labor negotiations, an air of hostility prevailed in the office.
prevail.meaning: be widespread in a particular area

prevail.example: Before the cricket match, Australia was heavily favored, but India prevailed.

profusion.example: When Maria reported that she had been visited by Jesus Christ and had proof, a profusion of reporters and journalists descended on the town.

rakish.example: As soon as he arrived in the city, the rakish young man bought some drugs and headed straight for the seedy parts of town.
rakish.meaning: having carefree, dashing and disreputable appearance

redress.example: Barry forgot his wife's birthday two years in a row, and was only able to redress his oversight by surprising his wife with a trip to Tahiti.
redress.meaning: an act of making something right, remedy, compensation
redress.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

rile.example: Dan is usually calm and balanced, but it takes only one intense glare from Sabrina to rile him.

tribulation.example: As of 2013, nearly 1.5 million Syrians have fled their country hoping to escape the tribulations of a civil war tearing their country to pieces.
tribulation.meaning: a cause of great difficulty or suffering

uncanny.example: normal Reggie has an uncanny ability to connect with animals: feral cats will readily approach him, and sometimes even wild birds will land on his finger.

veneer.example: Mark Twain referred to the Victorian Period in America as the "Gilded Age", implying the ample moral corruption that lay beneath a mere veneer of respectability.
veneer.meaning: thin superficial covering that hides the underlying substance

wanton.example: Due to wanton behavior and crude language, the drunk man was thrown out of the bar and asked to never return.
wanton.meaning: unrestrained, promiscuous, showing no moral restraints
